title: Printable Reef Live Rock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an experiment I'd like to conduct in the near future.

The idea is a "Live Rock" that is fully printable. It is of course not going to be live right off the bat, but it's designed to have a very high surface area, and be very porous. It has a decent shape/profile, and has several openings into it's interior, where the "web" structure creates a high surface area, but ability for life to attach and grow in there.

I'm just starting my first saltwater reef aquarium, and so I'm months away from a stable enough ecosystem to attempt this experiment.

Some general random thoughts that relate to the experiment and/or have created the idea:

  • ABS in theory is reef safe plastic
  • 3D Printing through FDM/FFF method creates textured plastic
  • With correct design, the part can be mostly hollow, and allow good water flow through it
  • High surface area throughout the body of the rock is easy with 3DP
  • With the model provided, the holes may allow filling the interior with coarse substrate, further improving surface area, and adding calcium buffering capabilities.

In theory over time life will begin to grow on/in this rock, and it will become just as "live" as natural live-rock. This could then support natural filtration much the same way regular live rock/sand do.

I have yet to print this, right now the design is fairly expensive to print, this is partially due to the way I've designed the structure. With some tweaking/future iterations I think I could get the cost down by a significant margin (50% or more reduction in material).

I may print it soon, but not right away, maybe I'll consider a smaller version of it as a test of how small I can reliably print the internal structures, and use that to adjust/tweak a V2 of this.

Thought I'd throw this up on thingiverse now in case someone else in the reef keeping hobby wanted to give it a shot.

Also, do NOT use PLA for this, PLA will break down under the saltwater/bacterial load in a reef tank.

Also DO NOT hold me responsible if this causes problems in your tank. As I said, it's an experiment ;)

As always, feedback & comments welcome.

And if you ever want any objects printed (such as this one) feel free to pop over to my 3d Hub at:
https://www.3dhubs.com/ottawa/hubs/glasswalker

Thanks for looking!

The part was designed purely in MeshMixer, using combinations of sphere shapes with deformations, I then performed a boolean union, and smoothed the result to get a nice organic shape. Following that I used cylinders with boolean difference to carve out the tunnels/cave. Ran another round of smoothing, then duplicated the part. The duplicate I reduced it's polygon complexity to low-poly, and then used make pattern to create the voronoi type pattern on the surface and interior. The original file I made hollow with 2mm walls. Following this I did a smooth with a negative amount, resulting in a slightly rougher appearance. Then I made both objects visible, and strategically placed cylinders to carve out certain "holes" in the shell where the voronoi cells were. Once I carved enough of these out to feel it would have sufficient water flow through the interior, I then joined the 2 parts together to get this result.

Ultimately it was quite quick and simple to do, and resulted in a neat looking "rock" to be used in the experiment.

Things I may want to alter:

More or less holes to support better flow-through, and/or manage to contain substrate if needed.

Changing both the diameter of the internal structure "rods" to optimize the use of material as much as possible, while maintaining the most possible surface area internally to support life growth.

I even considered running the version without the "skin". Perhaps getting the holes a little smaller, and structure smaller, as a result light could penetrate, further supporting growth of life internal to the "rock".

Anyway, all just ideas. For now the proof of concept needs testing in a real reef.

description.text:
I wanted to print something for my car, a Subaru Forester. I couldn't find any Forester shift knobs, so i had to draw my own. This is my first time using a 3D-program on my own, but i think it came out quite nice. :)

I only split it in two to make it easier to print. I used 6pcs of M3x20mm to hold the top and bottom part together. The knob itself i just screwed on to shifter without any nuts.

Drawn using "Onshape"
Printed mine in PetG(Torwell) on my Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2.

description.text:
Create your own custom stencil.

I needed to stencil a boat registration number onto the side of boat. Created this openSCAD script to work with customizer to serve this purpose and other stenciling projects.

State law requires these number to be at least 3" so I set the font size to 80mm. My printer can only print 2 or 3 letters at a time so I will be printing the entire registration number in multiple sections. See video http://dai.ly/x6f7330

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 medium

Infill:

doesn't matter

The length of the stencil is determined mainly by number of characters and the character height. Since some characters are wider than others the stencil script may not compute the length properly for your application. To compensate for this the Boarder_Right setting has been given a wide range.

To use the customizer script:

1) Enter your text
2) Select Font and style
3) Adjust Font Size for your application
4) Adjust Letter Spacing if needed
5) Adjust Top, Bottom and Left Borders if needed
6) Adjust Boarder Right to give your stencil the desired length

description.text: I present to you, the RepRap tie! Update 12.30.2011: Added minecraft stl one one 20x20cm build plate and individual pieces in zip file. Yet untested! Don't know how well the holes will print when laying flat, please leave feedback if you try. Update 12.30.2011: Added a stl file of a tie made from a stl file. Check out tie_stl.zip for source code. Not yet printed! For years people have made ties out of wood, and I adopted the principle for 3d printing. Could it be a world first? The basic idea is to take a 3d model, cut holes in it for string and then cut it into smaller pieces so the tie will bend. I'm not overly satisfied with how the ties sits around the neck, perhaps someone has an idea for a better solution? Also, any special ideas for a tie, just make a comment and I'll give it a go. :)

Print, drill, tie, wear proudly at at formal banquet, take picture, upload to thingiverse.
The .scad file is commented and includes a few examples. If you just want to render the plain tie, it only requires tie_plain.dxf.
You can tweak it to your hearts content, change the length, increase or decrease the number of pieces, thickness and whatnot. Note that even though most variables are changeable, it's not really that parametric, and you will need to tweak the values manually, especially if you modify the source (dxf/stl) a lot.
The plain example is a bit thin to my taste, so you might want to have a look at tie_plain_wider.dxf instead.
I like the look of printing the pieces standing up. If you like this as well, you could benefit from increasing the layer height to make them more visible.
Printing them standing up means you need to have good adhesion to the bed. I ramped mine up from 52C to 58C for PLA, and it worked fine.
When finished printing, drill out the holes (I used a 2mm drill bit) and fit a string through them. Take care not to run the drill too fast, as it will melt the plastic and can make visible seams on the front. The holes in the model could be bigger, but then they will be visible if your filament is not 100% opaque.
The sky is the limit here, there's no need for the pieces to be neither flat nor have straight cuts. Have fun!

print_settings.Notes:: Must be printed as presented (upside down) for threads and spray holes to be correct. I printed in ABS at 230 degrees C for best results. Raft only. PRINT UPSIDE DOWN!

description.text:
Water spray heads for my greenhouse. Will fit threaded 1/2" PVC fittings. Six direction flat spray pattern when printed correctly. PLEASE PRINT UPSIDE DOWN for perfect Threads. UPSIDE DOWN means print with the threaded opening UP.

I must give credit where credit is due. The screw base was gleaned from a fitting for a water hose (American thread) on this site. The extension and slotting is mine. Together they make sprayers that are working in my greenhouse right now.

Could not find spray heads at Home Depot to do what I wanted to do. The uploaded 123dx file can be altered for spray patterns, volume, etc. That's YOUR business.

2 STL files presented. One will produce head with 6 holes, one will produce 4 heads with 6 SLOTS.

This .STL file will print you 4 of them simultaneously. WILL PRINT 4 AS IS. I will upload the AutoCAD 123dx file for 1 so that you may alter as you see fit.

The STL file with 4 heads fits 1/2 PVC thread perfectly. However, you might wish to scale whatever sprinkler heads you create with the 123dx files up or down + or - 2% for good fil. You can figure that out.

These can make great replacement heads for lawn sprinklers. No more trips to hardware store. MAKE YOUR OWN.

Enjoy.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.21

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Must be printed as presented (upside down) for threads and spray holes to be correct. I printed in ABS at 230 degrees C for best results. Raft only. PRINT UPSIDE DOWN!

Took the American thread hose fitting .STL, shrunk to 75% of normal size, saved as .STL, loaded in AutoCAD 123d, created extension with slots, moved into position, saved as 123dx file, exported as you see here, copied and pasted 3 times for 4 nozzles, resaved .STL.

If you can improve it, please do so.

author: taishavargas928

title: Counterflow Air to Air Heat Exchange

description.text:
This is an initial design for a printable parametrised counterflow air to air heat exchange (HX). 
Typically counterflow HXs use 2 sets of interleaved plates, with the supply air flowing through one set and the extract air flowing through the other set.  Heat is transferred from the extract air to the incoming, thereby keeping the heat in the building while replacing the air.  In this design rather than using a set of parallel plates the airflows have been mingled together by creating a component that guides the airflows into a set of rectangular channels.  
The printed version shown only has three parts of the HX included, otherwise only the slots at the top and bottom are visible which makes it difficult to explain how it works.  In the printed object the bottom section is a regular grid with airflow in one direction surrounded on four sides by airflow going in the opposite direction, this is the heat transfer part of the heat exchange.  To speed-up debugging I have made this section quite short but the length, width, height and channel layout are defined as arguments to an openscad module HX.  The middle part of the component guides the air from separate channels into a set of parallel paths and then the top bit carries the air to different sides of the heat exchange, one for supply and the other for extract.  The middle bit and top bit need to be replicated onto the bottom of the heat exchange to multiplex/demultiplex on that end.  
A small version and a more usable version are shown with the bottom of the HX in place.  Outside air enters the right side of the upper triangle, warms up as it passes through the heat exchange and comes out of the left side of the bottom triangle then enters the building.  Air extracted from the building enters the right side of the bottom triangle, goes up through the HX and transfers its heat to the incoming air, exits the upper triangle on the left side.
The design is parameterised so the number of channels in the HX array can be set and these values ripple through the other components.  
This is an experiment to help understand the shape of the airmixer above the HX array.  I think the next thing to do is to break this into components so that I can experiment with different lengths and materials for the HX array, either printed or commodity extruded profile.  To assess the HX efficiency it will need a work harness, I'm thinking of a couple of muffin fans, an insulated enclosure, ideally mated to 100mm ducting and a microcontroller for instrumentation and fan control.
Decide on the size you want and generate from the scad file, it depends on shapes.scad so you will also need to get that.

comments.text: It would be interesting to make the channels out of a sheet material but I'm not sure how to fabricate it.  The key point is that the airflows need to be kept isolated, ideally the channels would be rigid enough so they don't require jigs at regular intervals to hold them in place otherwise the material of the jig would take up area in the HX cross section.
comments.author: pheolix

comments.text: Metal is actually a very good option, you just need to provide a thermal break between it and the outside walls. If the HX is completely inside the house then having a highly conductive matrix is great. Cost is probably a bigger concern.
comments.author: pheolix

comments.text: I haven't seen come across any high efficiency commercial MVHR units that come with a metal heat exchange, the latest vogue seems to be vapour permeable membranes which are made out of something like Gore-tex.
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text:
Thin metal sheets (
&
lt;
&
lt;0.1mm thickness) actually have very good properties for a heat exchanger; the thermal resistance along the length is high because it is thin, you can hold a strip of aluminum foil when you heat one side with a lighter.
comments.author: pheolix

comments.text: I'm agnostic to the HX material, the thing I want to enable is the use of local cost, robust, DIY materials.  To this end I've been working on a support frame that is located at either end of the HX which various sheet materials can be slotted into.  This will allow users to experiment with different materials until the selection criteria is clear.
comments.author: Proton

comments.text: You are right of course in the observation that the biggest advantage of a 3d printer in this case is to produce the complex geometry of the (un)mixer  :)
comments.author: pheolix

comments.text: Very useful!
comments.author: Proton

I remixed Qjr's no. 4 scalpel handle to work a little better for me. Here is the version that should fit the more popular size 3 scalpel blades. Still surprisingly durable and flexible in PETG.

I printed these at 100% infill, 0.1mm layer, 0.4mm nozzle. The trusswork is 0.5mm wall.
Cura will slice this correctly.

I added a few more edits to this version so the blade slid on nicely. I needed light pressure with pliers to get the blade to fully snap in, but I don't want to make it any looser. The sliding friction is more of a problem with this size 3 version. These are the strongest #3 printed scalpel handles I've seen so far. But please note, these are not sterile and can break. Be careful not to cut yourself when installing/using/replacing and I wouldn't recommend printing with PLA or any weak materials.

Also available: Scalpel Truss Handle - Size 4

title: E3D V6 mount for GEEEtech Prusa I3

description.text:
This part will enable you to mount an E3D V6 extruder directly on the standard x-axis carriage of GEEEtech Prusa I3.

Use some PTFE tubing to guide the filament from extruder to the hotend trough the hole on the front.

Fasten both parts with 2 Zip ties and it's done ;)

You may need to file a little bit of the middle connnector ring for proper closing of the lid.

X-Stop is optional, in case you need a longer stop for x-axis, like me.

How do you replace a 1970s Style sliding door handle that broke at 2pm today!  
Aha make use of SNIJLAB's bendy Plywood I  used 6mm Plywood for this the drawing and making was done just within two hours.

As the lock mechanis is a little more complex to draw I opted to blank the lock bar off and use this an outside door handle swaping it for one of the other plastic handles on the opposing door (opens the other way so its out side part is the same as the inside one that broke.  
Laser cut then paint in PVA glue before assembly will help to waterproof the laser plywood stick the bits together screw the four screws to hold it together and clamp the top and bottom on. wait for PVA to dry.. then paint with exterior paint.. I'm waiting for the PVA to dry now.  
It was fitted and working by the end of the day.. As my partner needed to work in the conservatory that night.

comments.text: Nice to see!
comments.author: SNIJLAB

comments.text:
It is still in use two years on from fitting it in fact I mislaid the drawings just getting a copy as another one of the plastic handles has just broken.
There are six pairs of these handles used on the conservatory sliding doors
comments.author: SNIJLAB

comments.text: The feature of bendy ply was to repeat the shape, the top and bottom boomerang parts hold the shape and the two 6mm thick half's of the ply are glued with PVA as well as held together by the 4 4mm screws.

Prothestic Hand

Remix: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1095104

In this video explains the process. Enables subtitles
https://youtu.be/uWL13vvi94s

This prosthesis has been designed to help those people with missing fingers.

It has been modelled keeping in mind the following principles:
-Keep the number of printed parts as low as possible.
-Keep the assembly process as simple as possible.
-Use the least possible amount of non-printable parts. In this new model, you can choose how to join fingers, using screws (2M), axes wire, or filament printer.

  • Leave openings in the model to allow the hand to transpire.
    -The previous model had another hand rotation system on the wrist, had more freedom. On this occasion I have modified the movement of the wrist using the fantastic idea of a union that uses hand "Flexy-hand" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:380665
    -I have also modified the system of tensioning the strings. It is safer than before and takes up less space.

The fingers flex when they are pulled by strings, such as fishing line, and extend automatically with the help of elastic cord.

A fabric strap with velcro is needed to secure the prosthesis to the arm.
You can download the original file blender, and thus can be studied and modified to improve its performance.

I hope to be successful with modifications. Thank you very much to " http://www.africadirecto.org/ " for suggesting changes and help to improve the model
https://youtu.be/9YwDoLA-IRM

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Notes:

-Dixtal pieces: printed flexible filament "filaflex" - 80% filling
-Hand, Wrist and Proximal pieces: 20% filling
-links and cover pieces: 20% filling
Tutorial: http://www.instructables.com/id/Prothestic-Hand/

description.text: This is a 3D-model of the Captain's chair as seen in Star Trek: The Original Series and frequently there in sat upon by Captain James Kirk. It was constructed by myself in Blender using a multitude of screenshots as reference. This is not only my first Thingiverse post but my first CAD-CAM as well so any constructive criticism would be welcomed.

this is a support for lm8uu linear bearing.
you need 6 m3 screw (10 or 16 mm long) and 6 M3 nuts, to connect the support to the y axle.
the left support needs 2 bearing in order to improve the y axle stiffness, hence the plate is more rigid.
I have printed it with PLA and Cura.

layer height 0.2
shell thickness 0.8

If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays Write secret messages to your friends and decode them with this ring. The Caesar Cipher, or Shift Cipher, is one of the oldest and simplest codes. Simply shift the alphabet by some amount and use that alphabet to write your message, or in this case twist the rings so that the letters line up in the right order. This is actually 2 nested rings that print interlocked but twist independently. It's big enough to fit on a finger tho it may be too big for regular wear. How to use: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8-q2hLL3Fco Both ends of the message chain will need a ring. To encode the message first choose a letter to be the key for the message. Then twist the rings so that "A" on the top ring aligns with the secret letter key. Write the key as the first letter of the message, then proceed to encode the message by looking for the letter you want to encode on the top ring, but writing the letter on the bottom ring. To decode the message, twist the rings to that "A" on the top ring aligns with the first letter of the message (the key). Then find each letter in the message on the bottom ring, writing down the letter above it on the top ring until the message is revealed. H:FVB HYL H ZWF UVD If you don't have a 3D printer, order a set for yourself on my etsy store: https://www.etsy.com/your/shops/CymonsDesigns/tools/listings/259345625

This is actually 2 nested rings that print together and turn independently. It's big enough to fit on a finger tho it may be too big for regular wear.
Both ends of the message will need a ring. The first letter of the message should be the what A in the top ring alligns to in the bottom ring. When encoding use the bottom letters for the top when decoding use the top letters for the bottom and decode away!
H:FVB HYL H ZWF UVD

comments.text: This is not a caesar cipher.  This is a simple substitution cipher.  The caesar cipher requires the message to be comprised of a perfect square and transcribing it in square where each row is the same length as each collumn.  Then you write it out in the opposite way you started.  So if you wrote the message from lest to right in the grid you would now transcribe things top to bottom.
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: This is too a Caesar cipher, or rather the key to a caesar cipher. You're describing a columnar transposition, another cool way to encode messages tho there's little you could print to help encoding or decoding that.

Cable McClippy was created to assist with storage of my music-gear related cables - mic cables, midi cables, guitar leads etc. which are anything up to 20ft in length.

Anyone with an interest in copper-free cables or any audio cables you wish to keep in good condition know that knotting your cables isn't great practice. Good quality (expensive) audio cables treated with respect will last for years.

Whilst velcro ties are great for keeping cables coiled loosely I often wanted to hang them up within reach of equipment. Having just gotten into the 3D printing realm I managed to pull this together in Tinkercad.

Cable McClippy is my solution. The design is intended to be flexible but since I didn't have any flexible material to print with I wanted something that would work with ABS or PLA. The cord that is used to wrap the cable and hook back through the body has been designed to flex.

Both materials can be brittle when thin. Printing this in PLA with 50% infill/0.3mm produced strong and flexible enough results. Print time should be quick - less than half an hour.

The hook is easily strong enough to hold the weight of the cable. The cord is the tricky part. PLA will snap easily if you simply bend it at one point.

The trick, once printed (and do it whilst still warm if you can) is to gently bend the cord across the back of your finger just enough to make the curve necessary to twist and pass thru the hole in the body. This will avoid stress on any single points which will cause a breakage in PLA or ABS.

I found PLA more resistance to breakage than ABS though I'm not yet getting really good prints from the ABS material I have.

I would assume this would be better printed in a flexible material (if the hook isn't so flexible it won't hold the weight of the attached cable). Would love to hear how that works out as I haven't been able to test that yet.

I found it printed better and stronger laid out diagonally across the bed - I seem to get better adhesion between the shell and infill this way.

Anyways, hope this is useful to others.. and please share how it prints in other materials ;)

  • Knob for RepRap Full Graphic LCD - adjasted a hole, I made it "D" shape for my Full Graphic LCD
  • RepRap Full Graphic LCD button (no modifications)

I designed this RAMPS1.4 box to have plenty of space for possible modifications/additions (for example Bluetooth module). Therefore it is a bit higher than KosselMini bottom triangle part, so you need to raise the frame by at least 15mm. To do this I used legs from this project Custom kossel parts by marbalon and additionally I glued to it a piece of foam which absorbs vibrations (I can recommend that, printer works a lot quieter).

For assembly you will need mainly M3x8 screws (for mounting Arduino Mega I used M3x6) and a drop of CA glue if you want attach "Kossel" text to the front of the RAMPS1.4 box.

comments.text: Hi, I like your design and the thoughtful inclusion of the LCD case.  I have a question about cooling.  Are you able to get away without any active cooling?
comments.author: jiabairen

comments.text: I have no issues with overheating. However I know one person with the same printer (but different stepper motors, and firmware - Marlin ) who used my RAMPS box and had to install additional fan. The fan was installed on the top face of the box, under LCD case, inside the box. So, looks like everything depends on your stepper motors and how you configured stepper drivers (if more current is needed then they will generate more heat).

description.text: My new YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnnw56J_TeOsF4M_F5pPPJQ Very much a work in progress! This is an odometer for filament! It should measure filament by the centimeter so you can have a real measurement for filament used! The base it attaches to slides on to the counter assembly, so you can chose different mounts for it, but the first mount is for a ToM endcap. I'm currently printing the first set of parts to validate the design, after some tweaks, I'll upload the first working design to share and build from! The next version will have a second resettable counter. I will also provide just the counter mechanism as a separate "thing" once I make sure everything works okay.

comments.text: How does that translate into length of plastic used? I realize you can make a number of assumptions based upon average diameter of plastic, fill ratio used, number of solid shells, etc. but that seems to be really crude and not really accomplishing the same goal as Erik's piece, as you also need to know the specific density of the plastic you're working with (a piece printed with the same exact settings in SF would print different in ABS vs PLA vs HDPE, etc.). All in all, weight will only ever crudely approximate CM of plastic used.
comments.author: valdi

comments.text: I hardly made an assumtion about anything... What I do know is that one kilogram roll has a certain value. I can therefore price my prints in accordance. Don't get me wrong, I like the idea of a counter. It's great for estimating how long a filament you have used and obviously how much is left. So if that is important to know, then Erik's gizmo is just the thing. Please think of my post/methood as an alternative not a replacement. It just gives another control point. I have also discovered that the weight/time relationship is roughly linear and therefore gives you the possibility to estimate weight/price from the time it takes to print.
comments.author: msmollin

comments.text: Truth-be-told, the best use I have for this apparatus which it would be best suited to fill is measuring filament for a print so I can cut deliberate amounts from a large stock spool.  Say I want to print multiple copies of an object using PVA but I don't want to have my whole spool of PVA exposed for multiple prints.  Print a single validation print, then measure and cut just enough for the batch (plus a little extra just in case).

author: enixidfrag

description.text: This is an electric toothbrush holder I've designed for Oral-B electric toothbrush charging base.

The Z-axis shafts on my acrylic frame Prusa i3 had to tendency to creep upwards as my prints progressed to the point where they would dislocate themselves from the bottom hole in the frame. After checking everything I could think of to fix the issue with no luck, I made this little add-on.

The shafts protrude from the top by 3mm so I made the captive hole 3.2mm deep, you may need to adjust this to suit if you have the same issue (or tell me how you fixed it in the first place, LOL)

The part is fixed to the frame with an M3x15 bolt and nylock nut. Just trial fit it first, mark where you want drill the holes and you're done.

comments.text: Must have a different Prusa i3 than me as mine came with pieces that look exactly like that except they don't have a hole in them as my rods only stick up through the top .5mm or less.

author: jaxfozzie

remixed_from.author: dc42
remixed_from.title: Kossel carriage truck for 2020 extrusion and V rollers

title: Remixed Kossel Carriage Truck for 2020 V-slot

description.text:
I remixed this for compatibility with optical (photo-interrupter) end-stops by adding a pin which enters the photo-interrupter slot.. I plan to use this along with the end-stop mount found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:450238

I moved the fastening holes vertically a couple of mm to make sure they are clear from the pre-load bolt passing through the carriage and also deepened the 20x20 hole pattern so that they pass through, which they didn't seem to previously.

This is my VERY FIRST attempt at an openSCAD deisgn, so all comments and feedback are welcome!

Thanks to dc42 and other contributors for a great design!

EDIT 20160414: After realizingthe endstop mount has a height (who would have thought?!) I changed the pin to only be 4mm deep and placed away from the extrusion so that it won't crash with the endstop mounting bracket.

author: Rickyychong

description.text:
UPDATE: 261017 - I have been experianceing a downfall with the command strips as the mounting solution, a few of my records have fallen over the past year. I changed the model to include drywall screws to mount the holders, they can be found here:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2608680

update: 121216 over 100 downloads and only one make!!! Please Please Please post some makes for me. please!

I printed out some record wall mounts and put up a lot of my favorite vinyls on my walls, but the mounts I found only supported the corners and they come quite far out from the wall so that the record doesn't fall. I used command strips to install them but the other mounts were too long (came too far off the wall) thus creating a moment on the command strips and some of them fell (from a very high distance). I also found that some of my old used records were tearing through the sleeves because the disc wasn't supported. I came up with these mounts that are very close to the wall, but you need one for the top and bottom. simply cut a command strip in half long ways (hot dog), and space them so that there is space above the record to be able to shift it up to remove and replace the record (see close up photo). there is a deep version if you have thicker sleeves.

install with the small side up, the large bottom allows for extra space so the record under it can be removed. the top side has a tiny shelf for the vinyl to sit on. happy making!

post your makes, show us your favorite records!

comments.text:
Hi,
How did you attach these mounts on wall?
comments.author: PaoloGar

comments.text: I used command strips cut in half which are pieces of mounting tape that are removable without wall damage.  I'm trying to think of a way to use picture nails for the next version, a few of mine admittedly fell after a long while.

The Rascal bar bracket allows you to electrically insulate and mechanically secure the Rascal, a small computer for art and science.

After printing two bars, you should drill and tap the cylindrical bosses. You can use either #4-40 or M3 fasteners. It would be nice if you didn't need to drill the holes before tapping. In the model, the holes are set to 2.26 mm in diameter, which theoretically shouldn't need predrilling, but with parts printed on my local Thingomatic, the actual diameter was smaller, so predrilling was required. M3 For M3 fasteners, I use a 0.100" drill (AKA drill size #39). You could certainly use a 2.5 mm drill. I suspect that a 3/32" drill would also work. For mounting the Rascal, a M3 x 6 stainless steel socket head cap screw, such as McMaster part number 91292A111, works great. #4-40 For #4-40 fasteners, I use a 0.089" drill (AKA drill size #43). I suspect that a 3/32" drill would also work. For mounting the Rascal, a #4-40 x 1/4" stainless steel socket head cap screw, such as McMaster part number 92196A106, works great.

Mount Whitney in California constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 1.7 million facets). This software was created using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

comments.text: It still is just source-code which means not in an executable format. You'd have to be able to compile the code. But the real reason is that the software isn't easy to use. It is command-line only and I haven't made any changes to make it easy to use. I started, last year, to write an App for the iPad and Mac but stopped because of work (I work full time and also teach in the spring...which makes all my home projects come to a halt). My plan is to get back to it but I have no time-line. If you have a map in mind you can send me the lower-left and upper-right Lat/Lon coordinates of the map and I'll be happy to make it for you. I could post a link on my public dropbox for you to download. Just let me know.

title: Greg's Wade reloaded extruder body for Rapman hotend

description.text: Quick modification for the arcol version of the extruder to fit the Rapman's hotend. The modification was to add holes for the screw head that protude above the flat surface opposite to the mounting holes. (Picture 10 on page 12 of http://cubify.s3.amazonaws.com/public/bfb/d100244_hot_end_manual_v3_1_0.pdf shows them) Print other parts from original (Gears, idler) Possible improvement (requiring more SCAD than I was in a mood to figure out) would be to rotate the entire hot end mount through 180 degrees. This would get the wiring in the opposite side of the extruder than the gears. (properly incorporating it into the SCAD file to have a file useful for the other hotends as well would be the other improvement..)

Made some magnetic hooks for my locker at work. Designed with space to glue in two 8mm x 3mm neodymium disc magnets that are available in most hardware stores or online. I added some black Sugru to the back after gluing in the magnets to give it some added grip on vertical surfaces. You could also use some plasti-dip spray to accomplish the same thing if you have it handy. They seem more than strong enough to hold my keys, padlocks, etc. that I designed them for. As with all magnets, the weight capacity will change dependent upon what you place them on. Should work well for refrigerator magnets, too.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

10%

After the Sugru cured, I had to shave it down a bit to get the clearance to the magnets set correctly and to even everything out. Pretty easy print. As you can see in the picture, it held a pair of scissors, a crescent wrench, and a set of keys on an 1.25 inch putty knife, so it should be plenty strong for normal use.

This is a most simple design for a laser cut LED candle. The LED is powered by a coin battery cell. You can use any LED. Most realistic is a special yellow flashing blink LED as you can find them on ebay.

Cut the candle from 6 mm thick milky acrylic. Best using a laser cuter machine at a school or a FabLab near you. Buy an LED and a CR2032 (or CR2020) coin battery. Bend the two legs of the LED together and put the battery in between with the longer leg to the (+) side of the battery (like for the LED-Throwies you find on the internet). Then insert to the LED with the battery into the candle. The round piece cut out for the batterie can be used as as stand, just insert it at the bottom of the candle.

title: Samsung Wireless Charger Stand v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Version 2 / remix of my original Samsung Wireless Charger Stand. I moved the charger down a few mm (to accommodate more phones of different sizes), increased the number of facets in all cylinders (for a better fit), and added an optional cover (so you don't illuminate the room at night).

The cover was somewhat of an afterthought, and serves no structural purpose, so it just hangs on with friction and a couple pegs. I might come up with a way to get it to clip on or something in the future.

Aesthetically, the base and top do not print in the same direction, so the grain doesn't match up. You can see this in the photos, it looks 2-toned in certain light. I'm ok with it. Maybe you could just embrace it and print them in 2 complementing colors.

As with the original, This is designed around the Samsung fast charge wireless charger (model EP-PN920). Tested and works well with the Note 5 and Galaxy S6, both with Spigen Slim Armor Cases, in both portrait and landscape orientation.

Here's the Tinkercad link so you can mess with it yourself. I've grouped the base and cover as two pieces fit together. You're able to download selected pieces individually. I've included the 2 separate pieces as well as the grouped .stl file here (in case that's useful to you).

Printer:

Makerfarm Prusa i3v

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You obviously won't want to print the top cover oriented as is. The angle of inclination is 15deg (for plating in your slicer). I used slic3r: Rotate -105deg about the X axis to get it to lay flat, face-down. If you do decide to print it face down (recommended), you won't need supports for the pegs.

I like using a brim for the base, but that's up to you.

I added some tiny tabs at the top edge of the charger hole in the base. These give some room for error, as I wanted the charger to snap in snugly. I found it makes for a nice tight fit. A flat needle file can remove some/all of the material to achieve whatever fit you need.

description.text:
This is the robot chassis we use on our robotics platform Muribot (http://www.moarobotics.com/products/robotics/), It's designed to hold a circular PCB with 8 IR sensors spaced along the perimeter (we used VCNL4010s), and 2 Solarbotics GM2 gear motors with our 3D printed wheels. If there's enough demand we'll upload a template for your own PCBs based on our design, otherwise you'll either have to wing it or buy a Muribot from our website.

Muribot Demo Video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZwpPmxrMcQo
